cards.title: Sport picture of the day / USA's shining light at the Women's World Cup
cards.rawTitle: USA's shining light at the Women's World Cup

item.title: Sport picture of the day: USA's shining light at the Women's World Cup
item.trailText: The light and shade cast over the USA’s women’s World Cup team as they take on Nigeria in front of the 52,000 crowd at BC Place stadium in Vancouver
item.standFirst: USA defender and player of the match Julie Johnston chases the ball through a beam of sunlight during the Group D match between Nigeria and USA at the BC Place Stadium in Vancouver during the Women’s World Cup

displayImages.altText: USA defender Julie Johnston chases the ball through a beam of sunlight during the Group C match between Nigeria and USA at the BC Place Stadium in Vancouver during the FIFA Women's World Cup.

headerImage.caption: USA defender and player of the match Julie Johnston chases the ball through a beam of sunlight during the Group D match between Nigeria and USA at the BC Place Stadium in Vancouver during the Women’s World Cup. Photograph: Andy Clark/AFP/Getty Images
headerImage.altText: USA defender and player of the match Julie Johnston chases the ball through a beam of sunlight during the Group D match between Nigeria and USA at the BC Place Stadium in Vancouver during the Women’s World Cup.
headerImage.cleanCaption: USA defender and player of the match Julie Johnston chases the ball through a beam of sunlight during the Group D match between Nigeria and USA at the BC Place Stadium in Vancouver during the Women’s World Cup.

image.altText: USA defender Julie Johnston chases the ball through a beam of sunlight during the Group C match between Nigeria and USA at the BC Place Stadium in Vancouver during the FIFA Women's World Cup.

cards.title: Sport picture of the day / US Open dangers await

item.title: Sport picture of the day: US Open dangers await
item.trailText: A nicely composed US Open preview shot of defending champion Martin Kaymer playing from one of the many vast bunkers at Chambers Bay
item.standFirst: A nicely composed US Open preview shot of defending champion Martin Kaymer playing from one of the many vast bunkers at Chambers Bay

displayImages.altText: Martin Kaymer of Germany hits a shot from a bunker during a practice round prior to the start of the 115th U.S. Open Championship at Chambers Bay, University Place, Washington.

headerImage.caption: Martin Kaymer of Germany hits a shot from a bunker during a practice round prior to the start of the 115th US Open at Chambers Bay, Washington. Photograph: Andrew Redington/Getty Images
headerImage.altText: Martin Kaymer of Germany hits a shot from a bunker during a practice round prior to the start of the 115th US Open at Chambers Bay, Washington.

cards.title: Picture of the day / Maasai Cricket Warriors

item.title: Sport picture of the day: Maasai Cricket Warriors
item.trailText: Maasai Cricket Warriors came together to raise awareness of rhino conservation by taking part in a charity tournament dubbed the ‘Last Male Standing’
item.standFirst: Members of the Maasai Cricket Warriors, a cricket team famed for using the sport to raise awareness for HIV/Aids, women’s issues and the devastating effects of poaching, pose with ‘Sudan’ the last male of his sub-species on the planet at the ol-Pejeta conservancy situated at the foot of Mount Kenya approximately 300 kilometres north of Nairobi. In the wake of Kenya’s bloodiest week – losing seven rhinos across the country – the group of Maasai warriors came together to raise awareness of rhino conservation by taking part in a charity tournament dubbed the ‘Last Male Standing’. Since 2007 there has been a 10,000% increase in poaching in South Africa alone, according to a report and Sudan is the last male of five nothern-white rhinos remaining on the planet

headerImage.caption: The Maasai Cricket Warriors played against the British Army Training Unit (BATUK) cricket team during a charity tournament called the ‘Last Male Standing’ at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Laikipia national park, Kenya. Photograph: Tony Karumba/AFP/Getty Images
headerImage.altText: The Maasai Cricket Warriors played against the British Army Training Unit (BATUK) cricket team during a charity tournament called the “Last Male Standing” at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Laikipia national park, Kenya. The Maasai Cricket Warriors actively campaign against retrogressive traditional practices, such as female genital mutilation and early childhood marriages, while fighting to eradicate discrimination against women in Maasailand. Through cricket, they hope to promote healthier lifestyles and to also spread awareness about HIV/AIDS amongst youths.
headerImage.cleanCaption: The Maasai Cricket Warriors played against the British Army Training Unit (BATUK) cricket team during a charity tournament called the ‘Last Male Standing’ at the Ol Pejeta Conservancy in Laikipia national park, Kenya.
